newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: ACCC says likely to support bank/insurance merger.
newsitem.headline: ACCC says likely to support bank/insurance merger.

text.p: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) chairman Alan Fels said on Thursday he would be likely to approve a takeover of one of the big four banks by a major insurance company.

"I could see it as being quite likely to increase competition with the entry into banking of a new significant force with a broad range of product offerings across the financial services sector," Fels told Australian Broadcasting Corp Radio on Thursday.
"So we would probably start from a position that there's a fair chance that that would be acceptable," Fels said.
"But we would certainly look at it carefully because it would create a fairly powerful new institution."
The ACCC is Australia's anti-monopoly watchdog.
The government-commissioned Wallis report into the financial sector recommended the end of the "six-pillar" policy between Australia's four major banks and two biggest life insurers.

But Treasurer Peter Costello said the government would not allow mergers at this time among Australia's big four banks -- National Australia Bank, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corp and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd.
The two big life offices are the AMP Society and National Mutual Holdings Ltd.
